title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce. The Act defines "article of fur" as any furskin or article containing furskin, and clarifies terms like "furskin", "raw or not dressed", and "dressed". It also defines "interstate or foreign commerce" and "import". The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and government entities under US jurisdiction. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. A "steel jaw leghold trap" is a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. No fur article can be traded if it comes from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or possess such fur, transport steel jaw leghold traps, or violate regulations set by the Secretary. Penalties apply for knowingly breaking these rules. Any person who knowingly violates regulations regarding fur trade from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and two years imprisonment for subsequent violations. The Secretary will reward individuals with half of the fine paid for providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement of the Act is outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, and seize containers and documents, and make arrests without a warrant for violations. The Secretary can detain, search, and seize containers, documents, and their contents under the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant for violations and enforce warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Seized items will be held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. Upon forfeiture, items will be disposed of by the Secretary. The Secretary can dispose of seized items in a manner consistent with the Act's purposes. Fur or steel jaw leghold traps taken in violation of the Act are subject to forfeiture. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators of the Act or its regulations. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, and the Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
